sourceDesc.bibl: Margaret Sanger Tells of Orient, Arizona Republic, Mar. 18, 1959

docBody.head: Margaret Sanger Tells of Orient
docBody.p: "The Orient is well on its way toward becoming the most eugenic part of the world," says Mrs. Margaret Sanger Slee, who with Mrs. Grace Sternberg returned Monday from the sixth international conference on Planned Parenthood Assn. in New Delhi, India.

Mrs. Slee feels that in India Prime Minister Nehru has made the difference in the work of that country. "I consider him the greatest living statesman. He includes every phase of Indian life in his five-year plan. . . economic and agricultural advancement, as well as care for and education of its poorer people. Nehru opened the conference and gave a very fine address. Under his leadership it seemed that all India was there together."

From India the ladies went to Tokyo where they learned that 80 Japanese firms, employing thousands of workers, have undertaken educational programs in birth control. "I predict," says Mrs. Slee, "that in two generations Japan will be the leading eugenic nation of the world, more so than the United States. They do not want to produce diseased children, and with the help of the government, are seeing that they don't.
